isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9200, 9300, 9400 Models Built After January 1, 1995 - ELECTRICAL TROUBLESHOOTING 1994-1995 DETROIT DIESEL SERIES 60 DDEC III ENGINES

svcsection.title: ELECTRICAL TROUBLESHOOTING 1994-1995 DETROIT DIESEL SERIES 60 DDEC III ENGINES

lev1.title: OVERVIEW
lev1.para: This section covers International installed components and circuits that directly interact with the Detroit Diesel Series 60 DDEC III electronic engine controls.

item.para: Provides operation descriptions of International installed components and related circuits that work with the Detroit Diesel Electronic Engine Controls (DDEC III).
Provides component locations for International circuits and connectors.
Provides troubleshooting charts for those circuits and components installed by International.

lev1.para: The Detroit Diesel DDEC III Troubleshooting Guide should be used to diagnose the engine control system, then use the troubleshooting charts in this section to troubleshoot the International circuits.
To obtain Detroit Diesel Engine Service information, contact your local Detroit Diesel Distributor.

lev2.title: Series 60 Electronic Engine Controls
lev2.para: The 1995 Detroit Diesel Electronic Control system (DDEC III) provides an electronic fuel control system, electronic engine protection and other operational controls.
DDEC III is standard on Series 60 engines and provides many engine/vehicle functions including:
Refer to the Detroit Diesel manual furnished with the vehicle for additional feature information.

Since each Series 60 DDEC III system is electronically programmable to individual owner specifications, the operating parameters will vary from vehicle to vehicle. These parameters include: maximum cruise speed, maximum road speed settings and many others.
The "Brain" of the DDEC system is the Electronic Control Module (ECM), located on the left side of the engine. The ECM receives inputs from the following International components:
The ECM receives inputs from sensors and switches, then outputs signals to the injectors, engine brake relay and other system components.

lev2.title: Engine Protection Systems
lev2.para: Three levels of engine protection are available with DDEC III: Warning, Derate and Shutdown. The DDEC III system monitors inputs from:

lev3.title: Warning
lev3.para: The Warning system (this is the default selection if no other system is selected) will activate if any of the parameters in Engine Protection Systems go outside of preset limits. With the Warning system activated, the yellow Engine Warning light and the red Stop Engine lights will illuminate. The vehicle operator must take action to avoid engine damage.

lev3.title: Derate
lev3.para: The Derate system will activate if any of the parameters in Engine Protection Systems go outside of preset limits. With the Derate system activated, the yellow Engine Warning light and the red Stop Engine lights will illuminate. The ECM reduces power (with a Limiting Speed Governor) or speed (with a Vehicle Speed Governor) over a 30-second period after the red Stop Engine light turns ON. This system has a Diagnostic ON/OFF - Shutdown Override switch (see below) .

lev3.title: Shutdown
lev3.para: The Shutdown system will activate if any of the parameters in Engine Protection Systems go outside of preset limits. With the Shutdown system activated, the yellow Engine Warning light and the red Stop Engine lights will illuminate. The ECM reduces power (with a Limiting Speed Governor) or speed (with a Vehicle Speed Governor) over a 30-second period after the red Stop Engine light turns ON. At the end of the 30-second interval, the engine shuts down. This Shutdown system has a Shutdown Override switch (see below).

lev3.title: Shutdown Override Switch
lev3.para: This switch is used to override the "shutdown" or "derate" sequence by resetting the 30-second timer, restoring power to the level when the red Stop Engine light turned ON. The switch must be recycled to obtain additional 30-second overrides. The ECM records the number of times the override is activated after a fault occurs.

lev2.title: Diagnostics
lev2.para: The ECM continuously monitors itself and other system components including sensors, connectors, and associated wiring.
If a minor fault occurs, the yellow Engine Warning light is turned ON and a fault code is set. This light indicates a problem that should be diagnosed as soon as possible.
If a major fault occurs, the yellow Engine Warning light and the red Stop Engine light turn ON. If this occurs, the vehicle should be parked as soon as is safely possible and the engine shut down.
Refer to DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING , for additional information on the diagnostics system.

lev1.title: OPERATION
lev1.para: Refer to circuit diagrams CTS-5119S for the following discussions on circuit operation.

lev2.title: Electronic Control Module (ECM)
lev2.para: The DDEC III ECM is connected to the International electrical system at three points:

item.para: International engine harness 30-way connector (273) connects to the ECM. This connector links the International switches, sensors, and data links, and supplies ignition power to the ECM.
ECM Power Cable connector (676) supplies unswitched battery power and an ECM ground path.
International J1922 connector (406) connects to the ECM's communication connector and is used to provide communications between the ECM and the ABS/Traction control system controller (if installed).

lev3.title: Unswitched Battery Power To ECM
lev3.para: The ECM receives unswitched battery power directly from the vehicle batteries through the 5-way, ECM Power Harness Connector (676). The power harness is connected to the battery harness at connector (675). Two in-line 15A fuses located on top of the batteries protect the system.

lev3.title: ECM Grounds
lev3.para: The ECM is grounded through the 5-way ECM Power Harness (676), which is connected to the negative battery terminal. The engine control system switches, low coolant sensor and the air conditioning compressor high pressure switch are grounded through the engine and battery harness at the negative battery terminal.

lev3.title: Switched Ignition Voltage To ECM
lev3.para: With the key switch ON, power from ignition adapter (494) is delivered on circuit 13D to ECM connector (273) terminal B3. This circuit is protected by 5A fuse F9-B.

lev3.title: Diagnostic ON/OFF - Shutdown Override Switch (260)
lev3.para: Refer to paragraph 1.1.2.4, page 2 and DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTINGfor switch function of this lighted switch.

This is a normally open (N.O.), momentarily closed switch. Switch terminal five is connected by digital input circuit 97AU to the ECM through connector (273) at location G1. Switch terminal six is connected to ground by circuit 97-GD. Closing the switch causes the voltage state in circuit 97AU to change to ground, indicating to the ECM that the switch has been toggled to the ON position.

lev3.title: ATA Data Link Connector (137)
lev3.para: The 6-pin ATA Data Link connector allows electronic service tools (EST) to communicate with the ECM. The data link carries serial data transmissions between the ECM and the electronic service tool and provides vehicle and engine speed information to the speedometer/tachometer cluster microprocessor. The data link provides communication capabilities for:
Data link connector (137) is located on the left instrument panel. Four of the six cavities have terminals. Those terminal/circuits are as follows:

item.para: Terminal A, circuit 98A(+) connects Data Link connector (137) to (514) Positive Data Link connector. Circuit 98(+) connects (514) to ECM connector (273) terminal C2. Connector (514) is also connected by circuit 47/48(+) through connector (421) to the speedometer/ tachometer cluster. Note that all the circuits in connector (514) are connected together by an internal bus.

Terminal B, circuit 98C(-) connects Data Link connector (137) to (515) Negative Data Link connector. Circuit 98B(-) connects (515) to ECM connector (273) terminal C1. Connector (515) is also connected by circuit 47/48(-) through connector (421) to the speedometer/ tachometer cluster. Note that all the circuits in connector (515) are connected together by an internal bus.
The positive and negative data link circuits are twisted wire pairs. The twisted wires protect the circuits from electrical interference.
Terminal C, circuit 97DL, supplies 12V ignition voltage for electronic service tools with the key ON. Circuit 97DL receives power from 5A fuse F9-C from ignition adapter (494).
Terminal E, circuit 97-GR, is a ground circuit for the electronic service tool. This circuit is grounded through (506) panel light ground adapter.

lev3.title: Yellow Engine Warning Light
lev3.para: The yellow engine warning light receives ignition power from fuse F4-A. The warning light ground circuit, 97AT, is connected to the ECM through connector (273), terminal B1. The ECM turns the light ON or OFF by opening or closing a ground switch in response to sensor inputs.

lev3.title: Red Engine Stop Light
lev3.para: The red engine Stop light receives ignition power from fuse F4-A. The Stop light ground circuit, 97AP, is connected to the ECM through ECM connector (273) terminal B2. The ECM turns the light ON or OFF by opening or closing a ground switch in response to sensor input.

lev2.title: Speedo/Tach Module Inputs
lev2.para: Refer to in CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for additional information.

The vehicle speed and engine speed signal to the speedometer/tachometer microprocessor is provided by the DDEC III ECM through the ATA data link circuits 98(+) and 98B(-) to data link connectors (515) and (514). Circuit 47/48(+) from (514) and 47/48(-) from (515) connect to the speedometer/tachometer unit at connector (421). See 1.2.6.3, page 6 for vehicle speed sensor.

lev3.title: ECM Programming
lev3.para: The ECM is programmed with vehicle component information, so the signal to the speedometer and tachometer is compatible. That information includes the following:

item.para: Vehicle Speed Sensor (VSS) enabled - YES or NO.
VSS type - Wheel or Tail (International uses wheel).
VSS teeth - International uses 16 teeth on counter wheel as does Allison.
Tire revolutions per mile or revolutions per kilometer (See Table 7.01).

lev3.para: If vehicle components are changed (different tire size, rear axle etc.) the ECM must be reprogrammed with the correct data.The speedometer/tachometer unit does not get reprogrammed. The Prolink EST is used for the reprogramming. Refer to DDEC III or Prolink manual for this procedure.

lev2.title: Idle Shutdown
lev2.para: The customer selectable idle shutdown feature shuts down the engine (does not shut down power to the cab) after a customer selected (programmed) length of time between 3 and 100 minutes.
The timer (an ECM function) begins counting down when:

item.para: The parking brake is set, which closes the park brake switch (268).
The engine speed is at idle rpm.
And the ECM does not see any clutch or brake pedal operation.

lev2.para: If these conditions are present, the ECM counts down the "customer selected length of time" until 90 seconds before the scheduled engine shutdown is to occur. At this time (90 seconds before shutdown), the yellow Engine Warning Light begins to flash rapidly. The idle timer can be disabled by depressing the accelerator pedal. This will allow the idle timer to be overridden if longer idle time is wanted. The shutdown timing sequence can be re-started by releasing and reapplying the parking brake.

If the idle timer shuts the engine down, fueling is stopped, but ignition voltage is still present to the ECM on circuit 16D at connector (273) terminal B3. The key switch must be cycled to OFF and back to ON before the engine will start.

note.para: The engine is shut down, but power to the cab is not turned OFF.

lev2.para: The ECM receives inputs from:

lev2.title: Low Coolant Probe (278)
lev2.para: The low coolant level probe is connected through International engine harness connector (278) circuit 34 to ECM connector (273) terminal H3. A signal from the ECM is sent to the probe on this circuit. The other probe circuit 34-G is connected to ground. When coolant level is below the probe, the circuit resistance changes, indicating to ECM that coolant level is below the critical level.

lev2.title: Cruise/PTO Control Operation
lev2.para: Refer to the Operator's Manual for operating instructions.

Cruise Control -Cruise control operates when vehicle speed is greater than 20 mph and engine speed is greater than 1100 rpm. Note that the vehicle speed signal used by the ECM in controlling the cruise system comes from the International installed vehicle speed sensor.
PTO Control -The PTO mode is activated when vehicle speed is zero AND the park brake is set (park brake switch (268) open). Releasing the park brake disables the PTO controls.
The cruise control and PTO system share the same components which include:

lev3.title: Cruise ON/OFF Switch (435)
lev3.para: Terminal five of the lighted cruise ON/OFF switch is connected by digital input circuit 97AE to ECM connector (273) terminal F2. Switch terminal six is connected through circuit 97-GC to ground. With the switch in the ON position, the voltage state in digital input circuit 97AE changes to ground, telling the ECM that the switch is in the ON position.

lev3.title: Cruise Set/Resume Switch (436)
lev3.para: Terminal three (Set) of the lighted cruise Set/Resume switch is connected by digital input circuit 97AB to ECM connector (273) terminal J1.
Terminal one (Resume) of the cruise Set/Resume switch is connected to digital input circuit 97AA, which is connected to ECM connector (273) terminal G3.
Switch terminal two is connected through circuit 97-GB to ground.
With the switch in the SET position, circuit 97AB is grounded, telling the ECM that the switch is in the ON position. With the switch in the RESUME position, circuit 97AA is grounded.
In the center switch position, terminals one and three are open, so the voltage state in circuits 97AA (resume) and 97AB (set) are both HIGH (5V).

lev3.title: Vehicle Speed Sensor (250)
lev3.para: The speed sensor is located at the rear of the transmission. The sensor sends a variable alternating current (AC) signal through engine harness connector (250) on circuits 97AJ and 97AK through ECM connector (273) locations E2 and E3 to the ECM. Refer to paragraph 1.2.3.for additional information on the speedometer signal input to the ECM.

lev3.title: Clutch Switch (294)
lev3.para: The clutch switch is a normally open switch, adjusted to be closed when the clutch pedal is in the released position. Depressing the clutch pedal 0.5 inch should cause the switch to open. One terminal of the clutch switch is connected by digital input circuit 97AH to ECM connector (273) terminal J2. The other switch terminal is connected through circuit 97-GH to ground.
With the switch closed (pedal released), the digital input circuit is LOW (ground). With the pedal depressed, the digital circuit is HIGH (5V).

lev3.title: Service Brake Switch (141)
lev3.para: The service brake switch is air actuated. It is closed when the service brakes are not applied, and opens when the service brakes are applied. One terminal of the service brake switch is connected by digital input circuit 97AL to ECM connector (273) terminal G2. The other terminal is connected through 97-GF to ground. With the service brakes released, the voltage state in circuit 97AL is LOW (ground). With brakes applied, the voltage state in circuit 97AL is HIGH (5V).

lev3.title: Park Brake Switch (268)
lev3.para: The park brake switch inputs a signal to the ECM that is used for the Automatic Idle Shutdown featureand for the PTO feature.

The park brake switch is air actuated. It is closed with the park brakes applied, and opens when the park brakes are released. One terminal of the park brake switch is connected by digital input circuit 97AV to ECM connector (273) terminal H2. The other terminal is connected through 97-GE to ground. With the park brakes released, the voltage state in circuit 97AV is HIGH (5V). With park brakes applied(switch closed), the voltage state in circuit 97AV is LOW (ground).

lev2.title: Engine Brake
lev2.para: Refer to the Owner's Manual for operating instructions.

With a Series 60 equipped International vehicle, the driver controls the engine brake ON/OFF and Selector switches, but the engine brake system is enabled (or disabled) by the ECM. The ECM enables or disables the Engine Brake Relay in response to the engine throttle position. The ECM enables the relay whenever the engine speed is 150 rpm greater than idle rpm and the throttle is in the idle position.

Note that the engine brake can provide engine brake capability when the vehicle is in the cruise control mode. For example, if the vehicle is in cruise control and going down a hill while the engine brake is selected, the ECM will control the amount of engine brake with respect to the cruise control set speed. The level of engine brake (6, 2 or 4 cylinders) selected with the engine brake selector switch will be the maximum amount of engine braking the ECM allows. Using the cruise ON/OFF switch, or applying service brakes or depressing the clutch will disable the cruise control.

If the vehicle is equipped with Antilock Brakes, the ABS controller communicates with the ECM through the J1922 connector (406). If the ABS system detects a possible wheel lockup condition, the ECM will disable the engine brake.
Engine Brake system components installed by International include:

lev3.title: Engine Brake ON/OFF Switch (434)
lev3.para: The lighted ON/OFF switch is a two-pole, single throw switch. Ground circuit 24-GA is connected to terminal six. Circuit 24AJ from the engine brake selector switch (433) is connected to terminal five. With this switch in the ON position, circuit 24AJ from the selector switch (433) is grounded.

lev3.title: Engine Brake Selector Switch (433)
lev3.para: The lighted engine brake selector switch is a three position switch (6-2-4 cylinder operation).
Switch terminal six is connected by digital input circuit 24AE to ECM connector (273) terminal K2.
Switch terminal three is connected by digital input circuit 24AF to ECM connector (273) terminal K3.
Switch terminal two is connected by circuit 24AJ to the engine brake ON/OFF switch.
With the engine brake switch ON, and the selector switch in the 6 cylinder position, the voltage state in circuits 24AE and 24AF are LOW (ground).
With the engine brake switch ON, and the selector switch in the 2 cylinder position, the voltage state in circuit 24AF is LOW (ground) and the voltage state in circuit 24AE is HIGH (5V).
With the engine brake switch ON, and the selector switch in the 4 cylinder position, the voltage state in circuit 24AE is LOW (ground) and the voltage state in circuit 24AF is HIGH (5V).

lev2.title: Accelerator Pedal (APS/IVS) (267)
lev2.para: DDEC III engines use an electronic accelerator pedal assembly that includes an Accelerator Position Sensor (APS) and Idle Validation Switch (IVS) function. These two sensors are integrated into one assembly. The APS/IVS sensor assembly is not serviceable, and if defective, must be replaced.

lev3.title: Accelerator Position Sensor (APS)
lev3.para: The APS acts like a potentiometer. Movement of the pedal results in a variable signal being sent to the ECM that is proportional to pedal position.

A five volt signal from ECM connector (273) terminal A3 is sent on circuit 99A(5V) to APS/IVS connector (267) terminal C. The variable wiper signal (varies with pedal position) is returned from connector (267) terminal B, on circuit 99 to ECM connector (273) terminal D2. The APS is grounded from connector (267) terminal A on circuit 99-R to ECM connector (273) terminal C3.

lev3.title: Idle Validation Switch (IVS)
lev3.para: The IVS is used to verify when the accelerator pedal is the idle position. A 5V input signal from ECM connector (273) terminal E1 is present on circuit 99B to connector (267) terminal E. Inside the IVS, the signal is applied to a wiper, which is grounded by circuit 99-GA. With the accelerator pedal at idle, the ECM sees a signal at ECM connector (273) terminal E1. Depressing the pedal causes the signal to go to a near zero value. Circuit 99-GA provides the IVS ground path from connector (267), through the cab and engine harness to the negative battery terminal. Terminal D at connector (267) is not used.

lev3.title: APS/IVS Interaction
lev3.para: The ECM analyzes the signals received from the APS/IVS, making certain that the signals fall within certain parameters. For example- if the IVS signal indicates that the pedal is in the idle position, the ECM expects to see an APS signal that indicates no throttle (or very little) is being applied. If the ECM does not see a logical response from both, a fault code will be logged. The APS/IVS timing cannot be checked using a multimeter.
